Column Comment.0: SEISMIC SET SUBTYPE: The seismic set type column is used to enforce arelationship between the SEIS SET supertype and its valid sub types. Values for thiscolumn must be the name of the table that is the valid sub type for this row of data.Valid entries include SEIS_LINE, SEIS_SEGMENT, SEIS_SURVEY, SEIS_PLAN,SEIS_WELL, SEIS_PROC_SET, SEIS_INTERP_SET or SEIS_3D.
Column Comment.1: SEISMIC SET: A seismic set is a super type of various types of seismic collections.
Column Comment.2: RECORD_ID: Unique identifier for the seismic record that was created duringacquisition.
Column Comment.3: CHANNEL IDENTIFIER: unique identifier for the channel on the seismic record.
Column Comment.4: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether this row of data is currently eitheractive / valid (Y) or inactive / invalid (N).
Column Comment.5: CHANNEL NUMBER: The number that is assigned to this channel.
Column Comment.6: CHANNEL TYPE: The type of channel that is used for recording the seismic data.May be time break channel, uphole channel, data channel etc.
Column Comment.7: EFFECTIVE DATE: The date that the data in this row first came into effect.
Column Comment.8: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row was no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.9: FILE NUMBER: The number assigned to the file on the recorded media, such as amagnetic tape.
Column Comment.10: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.11: REMARK: Narrative remarks relating to this row of data.
Column Comment.12: SEISMIC RECEIVER POINT ID: unique identifier for the point that is the reciever onthis channel for the record.
Column Comment.13: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.14: STREAMER IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for the seismic streamer that generatedthe data recorded on this channel.
Column Comment.15: SEISMIC VESSEL CONFIGURATION OBSERVATION NUMBER: Unique identifierfor this configuration of the seismic vessel.
Column Comment.16: VESSEL IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for the marine vessel.
Column Comment.17: VESSEL SF SUBTYPE: supports the super sub type implementation. Value may onlybe SEIS VESSEL.
Column Comment.18: X OFFSET: Used for marine data. Cross line distance from the receivers that createdthe recording on this channel to the shot position.
Column Comment.20: Y OFFSET: Used for marine data. In line distance from the receivers that created therecording on this channel to the shot position.
Column Comment.22: Z OFFSET: Used for marine data. Depth distance from the receivers that created therecording on this channel to the shot position.
Column Comment.24: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.25: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.26: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.27: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.28: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.29: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.30: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
